answers.author: Jacob Foos
answers.text:
I have not seen a case like that.  Out of curiosity, is it a restriction already enacted by your municipality or something you are looking at implementing?


I have not seen a case like that.  Out of curiosity, is it a restriction already enacted by your municipality or something you are looking at implementing?

answers.author: Jason Garza
answers.text:
Right now I am trying to research if a policy exists. There is some interest from elected officials regarding a policy along the lines of what I described. 
Currently, the only sort of process we have here in Austin is our affordable housing arm (the Austin Housing Finance Corporation) has the the right of first refusal for any City surplus property for the development of affordable housing.

answers.author: Jesse Himes
answers.text:
Hi Jason,
I found this on the Knowledge Network. It’s a detailed guide explain what the city of Tulsa, Oklahoma does with their surplus land.
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/305488/Tulsa_Asset_ManagementGuide
I hope this helps!
Jesse Himes, Knowledge Network Intern, jhimes@icam.org

author: Jason Garza
text: Does anyone know of a municipality that has a policy in place where any of its surplus land it wishes to sell must first go to either the local school district or the County for consideration before being opened up to the rest of the community for proposal?
title: City policy on surplus land
